levels.label: entry
levels.description: Holding a pencil with a functional grip and making controlled marks on paper.
levels.example_task: Hold your pencil like this (adult models tripod grip). Draw a line from the star to the circle without going off the path.
levels.example_response: Child holds pencil with a near-tripod grip and traces the path with reasonable control.
common_errors: Gripping the pencil in a fist rather than a tripod grip
Pressing too hard or too lightly on the paper

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using a consistent tripod grip and sitting with appropriate posture for writing.
levels.example_task: Write your name. Check: are you holding your pencil correctly? Is your back straight? Are your feet flat on the floor?
levels.example_response: Child writes name with tripod grip, sits upright, non-writing hand steadies paper.
common_errors: Slumping forward with head very close to the paper
Gripping the pencil too close to the point, covering the letters

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Maintaining correct pencil grip and posture consistently during extended writing tasks.
levels.example_task: Write for 10 minutes about your favourite place. Keep checking your pencil grip and posture.
levels.example_response: Child maintains good grip and posture throughout, writing fluently without fatigue.
common_errors: Starting with correct grip but reverting to a tighter or different grip when tired
Posture deteriorating during longer writing sessions

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Writing with speed and stamina while maintaining correct grip, posture, and legibility.
levels.example_task: Copy this passage as neatly and quickly as you can in 5 minutes.
levels.example_response: Child writes fluently with consistent grip, good posture, and legible handwriting throughout the timed task.
common_errors: Sacrificing grip or posture for speed
Legibility declining significantly as writing speed increases

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Forming some lower-case letters recognisably, starting from the correct position with adult support.
levels.example_task: Watch me write the letter 'a'. Now you try. Start at the top of the round part.
levels.example_response: Child forms a recognisable 'a' starting from the correct position.
common_errors: Starting the letter from the bottom instead of the top
Forming the letter as a recognisable shape but using incorrect stroke direction

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Forming most lower-case letters correctly using the appropriate start point and stroke direction.
levels.example_task: Write these letters: a, d, g, m, s, t. Start each one from the correct place.
levels.example_response: Child forms all six letters with correct start points and recognisable formation.
common_errors: Reversing 'b' and 'd' or 's' and 'z'
Forming round letters (a, d, g) clockwise instead of anticlockwise

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Forming all 26 lower-case letters correctly, consistently, and at an appropriate size.
levels.example_task: Write the whole alphabet in lower-case on the line. Make sure every letter starts from the right place.
levels.example_response: Child writes all 26 letters with correct formation, consistent size, and sitting on the baseline.
common_errors: One or two persistent formation errors (commonly b/d reversal or incorrect 'k' formation)
Letters correctly formed in isolation but inconsistent in connected writing

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Forming all letters fluently with correct formation maintained at speed in independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about your favourite animal. I will check that every letter is formed correctly even when you are writing quickly.
levels.example_response: Child writes fluently with consistent, correct letter formation throughout, even when concentrating on content.
common_errors: Correct formation in handwriting practice but reverting to shortcuts in independent writing
Most letters well-formed but one or two consistently incorrect under pressure

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Practising the shared movement pattern for one letter family (e.g., the 'c' family: c, a, d, o).
levels.example_task: All these letters start with the same shape — a 'c' curl. Practise: c, a, d, o.
levels.example_response: Child forms each letter starting with the anticlockwise curve.
common_errors: Not seeing the connection between the letters in the family
Starting 'a' from a different position than 'c' and 'd'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Forming letters from two or more letter families with the correct shared movement patterns.
levels.example_task: Write these letters from the down-stroke family: l, i, t, u. Then write these from the round family: c, a, d, o.
levels.example_response: Child forms all letters using the correct family movement pattern for each group.
common_errors: Mixing up the movement pattern from one family when writing another
Forming letters correctly but not recognising which family they belong to

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Sorting all letters into their formation families and using family knowledge to form letters consistently.
levels.example_task: Sort these letters into their families: n, c, l, a, h, o, t, b. How are the letters in each family similar?
levels.example_response: Round family: c, a, o. Down-stroke family: l, t. Retrace family: n, h, b. 'They start with the same movement.'
common_errors: Sorting most letters correctly but misplacing one or two
Sorting correctly but not being able to describe the shared movement

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using letter family knowledge to self-correct formation errors and to help peers improve their handwriting.
levels.example_task: Your partner is forming the letter 'a' by starting at the bottom. Which letter family does 'a' belong to? How would you help them fix it?
levels.example_response: 'The letter "a" is in the round family with c, d, g, o. They all start with the same anticlockwise curve at the top. I would tell them to start like a "c" and then add the down stroke.'
common_errors: Knowing the correct formation but not being able to explain it to a peer
Identifying the family but not connecting it to a fix for the error

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Forming some capital letters recognisably, beginning with the letters in the child's own name.
levels.example_task: Write the capital letter that starts your name.
levels.example_response: Child forms the capital letter recognisably (e.g., 'S' for Sam).
common_errors: Forming the capital letter the same as the lower-case version but larger
Starting the letter from the bottom instead of the top

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Forming common capital letters correctly (those used for names, days of the week).
levels.example_task: Write the capital letters for the days of the week: M, T, W, T, F, S, S.
levels.example_response: Child forms M, T, W, F, S correctly from the top.
common_errors: Forming 'S' or 'W' using lower-case movement patterns
Making capitals the same size as lower-case letters

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Forming all 26 capital letters correctly, at the appropriate size, distinct from their lower-case forms.
levels.example_task: Write the alphabet in capital letters. Make sure each one looks different from the lower-case version.
levels.example_response: Child writes all 26 capitals correctly, clearly larger than lower-case and with correct formation.
common_errors: Confusing capital and lower-case forms of similar letters (S/s, K/k, C/c)
Making some capitals too small or the same size as lower-case

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using capital letters fluently and correctly in all writing contexts, never mixing cases inappropriately.
levels.example_task: Write a short paragraph about your school. Use capital letters only where they are needed.
levels.example_response: Child uses capitals correctly for sentence starts, proper nouns and 'I', never mixing cases within words.
common_errors: Using capitals for emphasis or decoration rather than grammatical purpose
Occasionally mixing a capital into the middle of a word

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Forming the digits 0-9 recognisably with some adult guidance on starting position.
levels.example_task: Write the numbers 1 to 9. Start each number from the top.
levels.example_response: Child forms all nine digits recognisably.
common_errors: Reversing digits, particularly 3, 5 and 7
Starting digits from the bottom rather than the top

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Forming all digits 0-9 with correct start points and consistent size.
levels.example_task: Write these numbers clearly: 2, 3, 5, 7, 8. Make sure none are reversed.
levels.example_response: Child forms all digits correctly with no reversals.
common_errors: Persistent reversal of 3 or 5
Inconsistent sizing — some digits much larger or smaller than others

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing digits 0-9 fluently, correctly and consistently in maths and other contexts.
levels.example_task: Write the answer to these sums neatly: 14 + 23 = ___, 35 + 17 = ___.
levels.example_response: Child writes '37' and '52' with correctly formed, consistently sized digits.
common_errors: Digits correctly formed in handwriting practice but rushed and unclear in maths work
Confusing 6 and 9 when writing quickly

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Forming digits with fluency and consistency in all contexts, including two- and three-digit numbers with correct place value spacing.
levels.example_task: Write these numbers clearly with correct spacing: 108, 246, 350.
levels.example_response: Child writes all numbers with correctly formed, evenly spaced digits and consistent sizing.
common_errors: Digits too close together or too far apart, making place value unclear
Correct individual digit formation but poor alignment

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing letters on a baseline with some attempt at consistent size, using wide-lined paper.
levels.example_task: Write your name on the line. Try to make all the small letters the same height.
levels.example_response: Child writes name on the baseline with letters of approximately similar size.
common_errors: Letters floating above the baseline or sinking below it
All letters the same size regardless of ascenders and descenders

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writing letters with correct relative sizing — x-height letters smaller than ascenders, descenders below baseline.
levels.example_task: Write the word 'happy'. Make sure the 'h' is taller than the other letters and the 'y' goes below the line.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'happy' with 'h' as an ascender (tall), 'a', 'p', 'p' at x-height, and 'y' descending below the baseline.
common_errors: Making 'h' the same height as 'a' and 'p'
Not dropping the 'y' below the baseline

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing with consistent letter sizing and proportion, clearly distinguishing ascenders, descenders and x-height letters on lined paper.
levels.example_task: Write this sentence on lined paper: 'The big dog jumped high.' Check that tall letters touch the top line and tails go below the bottom line.
levels.example_response: Child writes with consistent proportion: b, d, j, h as ascenders, g, j, p as descenders, all other letters at x-height.
common_errors: Inconsistent sizing — some ascenders tall, others the same as x-height letters
Descenders not dropping enough below the baseline

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Maintaining correct letter sizing and proportion consistently in extended independent writing across all subjects.
levels.example_task: Write a half-page description of your classroom. I will check that your letter sizes stay consistent throughout.
levels.example_response: Child maintains consistent letter sizing, proportion and spacing throughout the extended piece of writing.
common_errors: Starting with good proportion but letters becoming uneven towards the end of the piece
Correct proportion on lined paper but losing it when lines are narrower

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Practising the basic diagonal join from one letter to another in simple letter pairs.
levels.example_task: Practise joining these letter pairs: 'in', 'an', 'it'.
levels.example_response: Child makes a diagonal joining stroke from the first letter to the second, keeping both letters recognisable.
common_errors: Lifting the pen between letters instead of maintaining the join
Distorting the second letter because of the joining stroke

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using diagonal and horizontal joins in common words, maintaining legibility.
levels.example_task: Write these words in joined handwriting: 'the', 'and', 'was', 'will'.
levels.example_response: Child joins the letters within each word with appropriate diagonal and horizontal strokes.
common_errors: Joining some letters but printing others within the same word
Joins that distort letter shapes, making the word difficult to read

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using joined handwriting consistently in independent writing, knowing which letters are best left unjoined.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about your holiday using joined handwriting throughout.
levels.example_response: Child writes in consistent joined handwriting, with appropriate joins and correct breaks for letters that don't join well.
common_errors: Attempting to join every letter, including combinations that don't work well
Reverting to print in independent writing despite joining in practice sessions

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Writing fluently in a consistent joined style that is both legible and efficient, maintaining quality at speed.
levels.example_task: Copy this passage in your best joined handwriting, then write it again as fast as you can while keeping it neat.
levels.example_response: Child produces legible joined writing at both normal and increased speed, with consistent joining patterns.
common_errors: Legible at normal pace but illegible when speed increases
Correct joins but letter formation deteriorating at speed

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using a finger space between words with a physical spacer or finger placed on the page.
levels.example_task: Write 'I like cats.' Put your finger between each word to make a space.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'I like cats.' with visible spaces between words, using finger as a guide.
common_errors: Running all words together: 'Ilikecats'
Using finger spaces inconsistently — some gaps large, some nonexistent

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Leaving consistent word spaces without needing a physical spacer.
levels.example_task: Write this sentence without using a finger spacer: 'The big dog ran fast.'
levels.example_response: Child writes with clear, consistent spaces between all words.
common_errors: Spaces between some words but not others
Very large spaces that disrupt the flow of the sentence

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Maintaining consistent, appropriate word spacing in all independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write five sentences about your best friend. I will check your spacing throughout.
levels.example_response: Child writes with consistent, appropriate word spacing across all five sentences.
common_errors: Spacing becoming inconsistent when writing quickly or concentrating on content
Spaces within words (e.g., 'be cause' instead of 'because')

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Maintaining correct spacing consistently in extended writing, with spacing proportional to letter size and appropriate for joined handwriting.
levels.example_task: Write a full page in joined handwriting. Check that your word spaces are clear but not too wide.
levels.example_response: Child maintains consistent, proportionate spacing throughout a full page of joined writing.
common_errors: Spacing that is correct in print but too wide or too narrow in joined writing
Word spaces that vary in width across the page
